Title: Confidential Computing: A Double-Edged Sword in Cloud Security

In recent years, hardware manufacturers have made significant strides in developing confidential computing technologies. These advancements aim to provide companies and governmental organizations with the ability to process sensitive data securely using shared cloud computing resources. Confidential computing protects sensitive data by isolating it in a secure area, inaccessible to other users and even the cloud provider. However, computer scientists at ETH Zurich have discovered potential vulnerabilities that could allow hackers to access these systems and the data within them.

The ETH Zurich research team, led by Professor Shweta Shinde, discovered security gaps while examining confidential computing technologies in AMD and Intel processors. The team aimed to understand the inner workings of these processors to develop an eavesdrop-proof smartphone based on confidential computing. The core of confidential computing lies in the trusted execution environment (TEE), a hardware-based component that isolates applications during processing. This isolation ensures data protection, even when stored unencrypted in working memory.

Hypervisors: A Double-Edged Sword

In a public cloud setting, applications are isolated using a TEE, primarily from hypervisors. Hypervisors are crucial for cloud providers, as they manage resources, optimize hardware usage, and ensure secure separation between different users on the same cloud. However, hypervisors also present a potential security risk. Under certain conditions, attacks on hypervisors can grant unauthorized access to data stored in the memories of other active cloud users.

Fundamental Limitations in Isolation

Despite the necessity of hypervisors for cloud services, there are inherent limitations to user system isolation and protection from hypervisors. The hypervisor must maintain some level of communication with the user system, and it must retain the ability to perform essential tasks such as resource allocation and virtual server management. The ETH Zurich researchers exploited these necessary interfaces, specifically targeting interrupt management between the hypervisor and the TEE.

In the dynamic world of dating apps, a new player is emerging with a mission to cater specifically to the LGBTQIA+ community. Queerie, an early-stage startup, is on the cusp of something big, seeking a modest $300,000 investment to bring its vision to life. This isn't just another dating app; it's a beacon of hope for those seeking connection in a world where isolation can be a harsh reality for queer individuals.

A Fresh Take on Dating

Queerie's pitch deck exudes a sense of freshness and vibrancy that's hard to ignore. With a clean and engaging design, it's clear that this isn't just a business; it's a brand with a heart. The mission is clear: to combat the loneliness that plagues many queer spaces and provide a safe haven for connection and love.

The Heart of the Matter

At its core, Queerie isn't just about swiping left or right; it's about addressing a deeper issue. The app aims to be more than a matchmaking service; it's a lifeline for those who feel disconnected from their community. The problem is real, and Queerie's solution is poised to make a genuine difference.

Despite the potential, Queerie's pitch reveals areas that need refinement. The team, while experienced, lacks diversity and seems mismatched for a startup of this nature. Questions arise about their ability to not just build a great app, but to nurture a company that resonates with its target audience. The absence of women in the team, for a platform priding itself on inclusivity, is a glaring omission.

The pitch deck, while visually appealing, falls short in conveying the unique value proposition of Queerie. It lacks the 'secret sauce' that sets it apart from the competition. A Question of Scale

The financial projections raise eyebrows, with a surprisingly low budget allocated for app development in a tech-driven startup. This oversight suggests a lack of foresight in Queerie's growth strategy, potentially stunting its scalability and appeal to venture capitalists.

Conclusion: A Diamond in the Rough

Queerie stands out as a promising venture with a noble cause at its heart. However, to transition from a brilliant idea to a fundable enterprise, it must address its shortcomings. With strategic improvements, Queerie could very well be the next big thing in the world of dating apps, bringing people together one swipe at a time.

title: Earthquake Brings East Coasters Together on Twitter: A Nostalgic Moment
post_content:
Title: The Unifying Power of Earthquake Twitter: A Nostalgic Glimpse into the Internet's Best

A few moments ago, I was sitting at my table, gazing at a vase of wilted Trader Joe's flowers when, all of a sudden, I felt the table tremble. It took me a few seconds to realize that I had just experienced an earthquake in New York. I was taken aback, but once I gathered my thoughts, I checked the tweets - or, as I now prefer to call them, microblogging site updates.

Within seconds, people on these platforms had already established the earthquake's magnitude and scope. They confirmed that it was, indeed, an earthquake and began sharing jokes and experiences related to the situation. This spontaneous event brought together people from various regions, including New Jersey, Philadelphia, New York City, and Massachusetts. Everyone was eager to share their feelings and reactions, reminiscent of the early days of Twitter, where users could express themselves openly without fear of judgment or irony.

The experience reminded me of the classic Twitter era, where people posted about their everyday lives without worrying about whether anyone cared. It was a time when you could share something as simple as "eating a ham and cheese sandwich" without any pretense. It was also similar to the early days of LiveJournal or Facebook statuses, where sharing your feelings was encouraged and appreciated.

In the aftermath of Elon Musk's Twitter acquisition, many users migrated to alternative platforms such as Bluesky, Mastodon, and Tumblr. While these platforms offered unique features, they lacked the sense of unity that Twitter once provided. Moments like these earthquake-induced microblogging frenzy remind us of the value of the "public town square" concept, where people can quickly learn about and discuss significant events, providing a sense of calm and camaraderie.

However, when the most popular town square becomes increasingly hostile towards those who don't fit a specific mold, we realize what we're missing. For instance, on Threads, users are discussing cherry blossoms, while on Facebook, people share local news and updates, but there's no mention of the earthquake.

Title: AGRNav: Paving the Way for Energy-Efficient Navigation in Occlusion-Prone Environments

Introduction

Robotic systems have been increasingly integrated into various aspects of our lives, particularly in controlled indoor environments. However, their potential extends far beyond, encompassing unpredictable and unmapped outdoor settings. Occlusion, or the blocking of a robot's sensors by objects, vehicles, animals, or other obstacles, poses a significant challenge in these environments, increasing the risk of collisions and suboptimal pathways. AGRNav, a novel framework developed by researchers at the University of Hong Kong, addresses this challenge by enhancing the autonomous navigation of air-ground robots in occlusion-prone environments.

The Challenge: Occlusions in Complex Environments

Air-ground robots, with their exceptional mobility and long endurance, hold great promise for navigating complex outdoor environments. These robots can assist humans in various tasks, such as searching for survivors after natural disasters, delivering packages to remote locations, and monitoring natural environments. However, their effectiveness is hindered by the presence of occlusions, which can lead to suboptimal trajectories and higher energy consumption.

The Solution: AGRNav Framework

AGRNav, introduced in a paper published on the arXiv preprint server, is designed to improve the navigation of air-ground robots in occlusion-prone environments. Comprised of a lightweight semantic scene completion network (SCONet) and a hierarchical path planner, AGRNav has demonstrated promising results in both simulations and real-world experiments.

SCONet: Accurate Obstacle Predictions

The SCONet component of AGRNav predicts the distribution of obstacles in an environment and their semantic features using a deep learning approach that requires minimal computational resources. By capturing contextual information and occlusion area features, SCONet enables accurate obstacle predictions.

Hierarchical Path Planner: Energy-Efficient Paths

The hierarchical path planner in AGRNav uses the predictions made by SCONet to plan optimal, energy-efficient aerial and ground paths for a robot to reach a given location. By efficiently searching for energy-saving paths, the framework minimizes collisions and reduces energy consumption.

title: 3D Magnetic Recording: A Breakthrough in Data Storage
post_content:
Title: A Revolutionary Approach to Data Storage: 3D Magnetic Recording

A groundbreaking study by researchers from NIMS, Seagate Technology, and Tohoku University has unveiled a promising advancement in the field of hard disk drives (HDDs). The team has successfully demonstrated the feasibility of multi-level recording using a three-dimensional magnetic recording medium, paving the way for a new era of data storage solutions.

Currently, data centers rely on hard disk drives utilizing perpendicular magnetic recording (PMR) to store information at densities of approximately 1.5 Tbit/in². As data demands continue to rise, the need for higher areal densities has become crucial. This calls for a high anisotropy magnetic recording medium, such as FePt grains combined with heat-assisted laser writing, which is the basis for heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR). HAMR can maintain areal recording densities of up to 10 Tbit/in², with the potential for even higher densities when storing multiple recording levels.

The research team, whose study was published in Acta Materialia, has made strides in arranging FePt recording layers in a three-dimensional manner. By fabricating lattice-matched, FePt/Ru/FePt multilayer films, with Ru as a spacer layer, the team enabled the possibility of three-dimensional recording. Measurements of the magnetization revealed that the two FePt layers have different Curie temperatures, allowing for adjustments in laser power when writing and thus making three-dimensional recording possible.

Simulations using a media model that mimics the microstructure and magnetic properties of the fabricated media further demonstrated the principle of 3D recording. This innovative approach has the potential to significantly increase recording capacity by stacking recording layers in three dimensions. Consequently, fewer hard disk drives would be required to store the same amount of digital information, leading to energy savings for data centers.

The researchers aim to further refine this technology by developing processes to reduce the size of FePt grains, improve orientation and magnetic anisotropy, and stack more FePt layers. Doing so would result in a media structure suitable for practical use in high-density HDDs, revolutionizing the data storage landscape.

This new PCRAM device holds the potential to replace existing memory technologies, such as DRAM and NAND flash memory, and pave the way for neuromorphic computing in artificial intelligence hardware.

Traditional phase change memory has faced issues like high fabrication costs and substantial power consumption during operation. NAND flash memory, on the other hand, offers slower read/write speeds but preserves data even when the power is cut off due to its non-volatile nature.

Phase change memory, however, combines the advantages of both DRAM and NAND flash memory, providing high speed and non-volatile characteristics. Apple has recently inched closer to revolutionizing productivity for users across various devices. In December 2023, Apple filed a patent application titled "Continuity of applications across devices." The second device would automatically recognize the item and open the relevant app, creating a seamless experience for the user.

While Apple has a reputation for filing patents that may not always result in consumer-facing features, this new patent application suggests that the tech giant is exploring exciting possibilities for enhancing cross-device productivity. post_title: Will the solar eclipse burn out the camera on your iPhone? Here's what experts say
title: Capture the 2024 Solar Eclipse Safely: iPhone Camera Tips
post_content:
Title: The 2024 Solar Eclipse: Capturing the Spectacle Without Harming Your Smartphone

On Monday, millions of people across North America will witness a rare celestial event - a total solar eclipse. As the moon passes between the Earth and the sun, daytime skies will darken briefly. However, it's crucial to remember that looking directly at the sun, even when it's partially covered, can cause severe eye damage. This rule applies to your smartphone's camera as well.

Most experts, including phone manufacturers and accessory makers, warn that prolonged exposure of your smartphone's camera sensor to the sun's light can result in damage. Runar Bjorhovde, an analyst at Canalys, emphasizes that while it's possible to buy a solar filter for a smartphone camera at a reasonable price, the primary concern should be the safety of the viewer's eyes, which are far more delicate and challenging to repair or replace than a smartphone camera.

The team at Halide Camera, creators of an iOS app offering manual controls for iPhone cameras, advises capturing images only during the eclipse itself. This is when the sun is either obscured by clouds or the moon, reducing the intensity of its light and making it safer for your phone's sensor. Moreover, your phone camera can adjust its exposure levels, light speed, and f/stop more effectively when the sun is obstructed.

During other phases of the eclipse, when the sun is more exposed, your phone's images will likely be blurry, overly bright, and unusable. However, with the right equipment, capturing a visually accurate shot of the eclipse is possible. This includes a telephoto lens attachment for distant capture, a solar filter, and a tripod or selfie stick for stability.

Remember, the solar eclipse is a magnificent natural phenomenon. Prioritize your eye safety and enjoy the spectacle. If you're determined to capture images, do so wisely and consider investing in the necessary equipment to protect your smartphone camera.

title: AI Job Reskill Plan: 95M in 10yrs
post_content:
Title: The AI-Enabled Workforce Consortium: A New Hope for Jobs Impacted by AI

Introduction

In an era where artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly becoming a significant part of our lives, the impact on the job market is undeniable. To address this issue, some of the world's leading tech companies have formed the AI-Enabled Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Workforce Consortium. This group includes Accenture, Eightfold, Google, IBM, Indeed, Intel, Microsoft, and SAP, along with six advisers. Together, they aim to help those who have lost or will lose their jobs due to AI adoption to upskill or reskill and reenter the workforce.

The Impact of AI on Jobs

The consortium was formed in response to the growing number of jobs lost to AI. Companies like UPS and IBM have already acknowledged layoffs and hiring freezes due to AI adoption. According to a study from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, US companies have cut more than 4,600 jobs as they seek new AI-ready hires or replace positions with AI. While many of these cuts are a result of AI innovations developed by ICT participants, the consortium members recognize the need to help workers find new careers in other roles.

Ambitious but Necessary Goals

The AI-Enabled Workforce Consortium has set a goal to "positively impact over 95 million individuals around the world over the next 10 years." To achieve this, each company has announced specific plans:

1. Cisco aims to train 25 million people with cybersecurity and digital skills by 2032.
2. IBM plans to skill 30 million individuals by 2030 in digital skills, including 2 million in AI.
3. Intel aims to train more than 30 million people with AI skills for current and future jobs by 2030.
4. Microsoft will train and certify 10 million people from underserved communities with in-demand digital skills by 2025.
5. SAP hopes to upskill 2 million people worldwide by 2025.
6. Google has already announced EUR 25 million in funding to support AI training and skills for people across Europe.

title: Measuring Artificial General Intelligence: Challenges and Progress
post_content:
Title: The Pursuit of Artificial General Intelligence: A New Frontier in AI Research

Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), a futuristic concept of machines that possess broad cognitive abilities akin to humans, has become the driving force behind the missions of OpenAI, Amazon, Google, Meta, and Microsoft. This revolutionary technology, once it becomes a reality, could pose existential risks to humanity, as warned by leading AI scientists in a research paper published in the journal Science. But what exactly is AGI, and how will we recognize it when it arrives?

AGI: The Ambiguous Concept

AGI is not to be confused with generative AI, which involves AI systems that generate new documents, images, and sounds. Instead, AGI is a more abstract idea, not a technical term. According to Geoffrey Hinton, a pioneering AI scientist, "I don't think there is agreement on what the term means. I use it to mean AI that is at least as good as humans at nearly all of the cognitive things that humans do." Hinton prefers the term superintelligence for AGIs that surpass human capabilities.

The term AGI harks back to the original vision of artificial intelligence, which aimed to build thinking machines before AI research branched into specialized and commercially viable subfields such as face recognition and speech-recognizing voice assistants like Siri and Alexa. Mainstream AI research shifted away from this ambitious vision, but a small group of early proponents continues to pursue the idea of AGI.

Measuring AGI: A Work in Progress

Without a clear definition, measuring AGI remains a challenge. "Twenty years ago, I think people would have happily agreed that systems with the ability of GPT-4 or (Google's) Gemini had achieved general intelligence comparable to that of humans," Hinton said. "But now that AI can do that, people want to change the test."

Improvements in autoregressive AI techniques and massive computing power have led to impressive chatbots. However, AGI requires technology that can perform just as well as humans in a wide variety of tasks, including reasoning, planning, and the ability to learn from experiences.

Introduction

The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into the workplace has sparked a wave of disruption, raising concerns about job displacement while also offering opportunities for empowerment and growth. This article explores the impact of generative AI on employment, focusing on the balance between job destruction and value creation.

The Dilemma of AI and Job Displacement

In recent years, AI has demonstrated the potential to automate various tasks, potentially replacing human workers in the process. The use of AI as a virtual assistant, as shared in a previous ZDNET article, highlights the technology's capacity to save time and resources. However, as reader @f8lee pointed out, this advancement may come at the cost of job opportunities for those seeking "grunt work" experience.

While AI has the potential to replace certain jobs, it also presents an opportunity for businesses and individuals to enhance their productivity. By leveraging AI tools, budget-constrained individuals and small businesses can increase their output, compete with larger players, and potentially regain personal time. Furthermore, AI can help those with linguistic or artistic challenges to produce output that might have otherwise been unattainable.

The transition from human-operated telephone systems to electronic switching is a prime example. Employers, employees, and educational institutions must adapt to the AI revolution by encouraging continuous learning, investing in AI training programs, and incorporating AI literacy into curricula.
